FacilityName: Marathon Pipe Line LLC - East Sparta

General Emergency Response

-Emergency alert systems;
-Periodic emergency training for employees;
-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies;
-Emergency training/exercises with facility personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies;
-Mutual Aid with Local Fire Departments; and
-Participation with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) or equivalent.

The East Sparta Butane Batch Blending process was designed and constructed following the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58 [2020 at the time of construction]) requirements for LPG storage. In addition to the presence of appropriate release prevention controls, an Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP) is in place for the Facility with response activities are coordinated with the East Sparta Fire Department and supporting Marathon refinery fire department assets.

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The East Sparta Station has an excellent record of accident prevention. The terminal keeps records for all accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility. As this is a new process, there have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the chemical release of materials defined under the EPA RMP regulation.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The East Sparta Station is identified as a Non-Responding Stationary Source and, as such, utilizes outside sources (East Sparta Fire Department and Marathon refinery) for offensive-type response actions.

In the event of an emergency involving the East Sparta Butane Batch Blending process, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the East Sparta Fire Department and Marathon refinery fire response located in Canton, OH to request their assistance. The Facility maintains a trained (annua

lly) incipient fire capability. The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the East Sparta Fire Department which has Butane process response training prior to startup.  In addition to startup training, the Fire Department participates in annual training/coordination events and is contacted about potential full-scale exercises.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Marathon is continually striving to make the East Sparta Station the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.

In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Marathon looks for, and seeks employee input, on process safety improvements per its Employee Participation program.  All process safety events (as defined in API 754) are electronically recorded, reviewed and/or investigated via root-cause analysis (ex. TapRooT) per corporate policy.  Additionally, the East Sparta Station works cooperatively with the community to address any concerns.
